documents.document: I hear every second word works @kristenauthor @AirPowerHistory
What self-respecting historian has a tidy desk @kristenauthor? I'd be worried if it was.
I cant wait to read your forthcoming journal article @AuthorClaireG!
A reflection of state based recruiting @AuthorClaireG? WA men associated in civilian life shared common exp on WF. 11Bn, 16Bn, 44Bn etc.
Absolutely @AuthorClaireG. I write about Lyons in "Beyond Surrender". Have you met @iandloftus? Similar interests between #twitterstorians!
Sure do @AuthorClaireG. McKinnon was captured at Fromelles and died from GSW at a German field hospital at Douai eight days later.
Sure am @AuthorClaireG. Fair few WA lads captured at Pozières, Mouquet Farm, Bullecourt & Lagnicourt. Happy to help wherever I can!
Thanks @rjm037!
Theres plenty of that going on too @rjm037. Submitting in June.
1200 pages into @StephenKing's #TheStand. I get a prize for finishing it, right?
The director's cut @ChrisBernath? 20 mins of "The end" by The Doors as the finale never lost its sense of irony.
I like to think of it as my own 'Limitless' experience @Sjgray86
I wish it would happen more often @Sjgray86
Same thing happened to me recently. I felt productive without typing a single word. @Sjgray86
Well that escalated quickly. https://t.co/OzzJIumZz5
Absolutely @mesutuyar10. None of the 60 Aust POW died Ottoman captivity were officers. Of the 337 Aust POW died in Germany, 2 were officers.
Sorry, @iandloftus. Mentioned in Dispatches.
Conditions there were pretty good @nigel_atter. Hardly a hell-hole, as this photo of Australian officers fro May 19… https://t.co/IQvRkpOio8
Escaped, recaptured and an MC for his efforts @iandloftus. I write about Lyons in "Beyond Surrender" & may have some material for you.
Captured Aust officers considered Krefeld "one of the best" camps in Germany @nigel_atter. Pre-war Hussar barracks… https://t.co/XaPpcLny4D
The one, the only. @Taff_Gillingham @greatwarfilms
Good qn though. I'll see what I can dig up. @lawrencema_85b
Aust POW data cross-referenced with @CWGC and @AWMemorial @lawrencema_85b. Ottoman/German POW stats would be British. 1/2
Close to 1000 Australians taken POW German troops on Western Front May-Nov 1916. All but 26 survived the war and re… https://t.co/xE69K9kKkV
Great photo @FrancesBekafigo!
Grim lessons learned on the #Somme. II Corps notes, August 1916. https://t.co/ackKGRUbyc
Remember the dead but fight like hell for the living. Great #RemembranceDay address by @jeff_kennett this morning. https://t.co/LMi43nXvFn
400 men & 25 officers @AustGreatWar
Mustangs supporting Old Faithful. #3RAR #77SqnRAAF https://t.co/hWlMu31zg3
Reading @StephenKing while @Stranger_Things soundtrack plays. Could there be a creepier, more suspenseful way to spend a Friday afternoon?
Wally Peeler reflecting on his VC action at Broodseinde in 1966: "I never saw the faces of those I killed ... Simpl… https://t.co/M6oepG3Zn1
Questionnaire Bill Gammage sent Joynt VC for "Broken Years" research in 1967. Feelings before first action?: "Afrai… https://t.co/mQDLOnT7K2
Great value to those writing histories of recent conflicts too @LearningArmy @DeadPrussianPod @AWM_OHP
Curious Beersheba will be the major commemorative focus @PPDaley. By 31 Oct 17, AIF lost 36,000 casualties in 8 wks Passchendaele fighting.
Hold your horses folks, #Beersheba's centenary is next year. This piece by @PPDaley on the complexities of commemo… https://t.co/VjrrjM93jE
Enjoyed looking through @AWMemorials' Hudson bomber today. Inadequate armament against Japanese Zeros earned it nic… https://t.co/uLVGAwqFlp
Flares would make perfect sense @ReturnedFTF.
Would I be right in thinking those light trails are mortars @ReturnedFTF? Can't think of too many rounds with such a high-trajectory.
Yours and @JohnBlaxland's were the standouts this morning @RhysCrawley. Congratulations both!
You would think so @AustraliaWW1. But #Somme weather reports show a number of fine/sunny days in October 1916: https://t.co/71b4fPVOkz
Haig also met Gough that day to discuss operational planning on #Somme: "Watch weather and execute plans after 3 fine days" @AustraliaWW1
Initial comments from my last substantive chapter. "OK in broad. Some repetition and much verbose languague." Looking forward to the rest!
I don't have a house in Scotland or can churn out a draft in 27 writing days, but coffee and Mogwai are my staples too @RobertFoleyKCL
If thats the case, prolly relaxed atmosphere compared to France too. Interested to hear what you turn up! @AimeeFoxGodden
Doubt it worked on an official level, but maybe on informal battn/company/platoon level. Probably no different from Brits @AimeeFoxGodden
"No other Australian more influential than Bean in shaping the way #FWW is remembered and commemorated". My latest… https://t.co/t7ZjZsL7lK
@Psy_Historian Downloaded, saved and printed. Ready to rip into new and engaging aspect of RAF Bomber Command.
"In a word, the crew simply disappeared". @WW2Researcher @FrancesBekafigo
I'll shout the first round of pink gin @WWATMD @kpbushnell
Historians skeptical sea monster involved in sinking of a German U-Boat in First World War. Who would have thought? https://t.co/MRXcnEr1YG
Thanks @AndrewFaulkner9 @issuu. Glad you enjoyed it! @AWMemorial
Get it written @ClaireDavisPHD, but also trust the writing process @PhDForum @PaulineZardo
Great photo @FrancesBekafigo. Palpable sense of anticipation and dread as engines idled and crews ran through pre-flight checks.
Curious that over 8 million combatants taken prisoner in FWW @Artistwar, yet few artworks represent that wartime experience.
@WW1_Series Any idea of the air-speed velocity of an unladen carrier pigeon?
Its the small details of that film that resound with me. Reveted trenches made by crew who fought the war. @greatwarfilms @wordpressdotcom
Interesting little war memorial near home. Wonder when Iraq and Afghanistan will be commemorated on local memorials… https://t.co/SYVRZ7nxyT
I didnt listen to mine either @Vanda_Wilcox @Mick_Cook. Excrutiating!
Me too @AmeliaVonVixen. Absolutely nothing like the book.
And to top it all off, singles you out as an "Adelaide journalist" @AndrewFaulkner9. Blistering.
The book is much better @KarlJames_1945 @StephenKing
Academia at its best @Brynley_H. Strange he wasn't a reviewer though.
Watching Kubrick's adaptation of The Shining for the first time in decades. Unlike @StephenKing's book, it hasn't aged well.
*inhales to the tune of Up There Cazaly* @stephenstockwel
Who would have thought @KarlJames_1945? https://t.co/xq8pZq8Zzi
Thabks chum! @Brynley_H
Not mentioned was the development of the bangalore torpedo for wirecutting @ProfPeterDoyle. Raids=laboratory for technical/tactical success.
Phosphorpus too @ProfPeterDoyle, as @Brynley_H mentioned. Nasty, grisly stuff.
On the Western Front, raiding success depended on effective planning, preparation, a good fireplan and surprise: https://t.co/NjXel33yzS
Pte Alfred Jackson, 54Bn AIF. Captured at Fromelles and spent remainder of FWW in Germany. Still retained sense reg… https://t.co/YTnMfccBuC
New street nr home. Named after Joe Honeysett, snr public servant 1920s-50s. Served WW1, captured by Germans, won M… https://t.co/Rkp9RwysRs
Pretty sure there was a Pte Baldrick in that formation @prior_robin @ProfPeterDoyle. No idea what battalion.
Not so much in memoirs @ProfPeterDoyle. Moreso in raid orders, after action reports and lessons learnt pamphlets.
Some regularity in 1917 @ProfPeterDoyle. Also rendered enemy MG positions unusable during withdrawal across NML. No idea of numbers made.
No 28 'stinkpot' more practical @ProfPeterDoyle. Horrid overwhelming smell forced enemy in dugouts to surface. https://t.co/2nUkF51pGx
Not just Punjabi Muslim/Pathan POWs @SubedarKhanOrg. Two Indigenous Australian POW ended up at Zossen too. See: https://t.co/GXqyA5aZIV
This pattern more common for AIF in mid-16 near Armentieres @ProfPeterDoyle. Flanged cog made by Engineers with ent… https://t.co/PUiKfocZd7
Raiding icon, but practically useless in a gunfight @ProfPeterDoyle. Revolvers, grenades more effective at close quarters when raid sprung.
A great piece on #3RAR at Maryang San by @AWMemorial historian Mick Kelly. Fought this week 65 years ago in Korea: https://t.co/csxMmhfTWX
For more on Noble and his current deployment to Iraq, see https://t.co/STSWiJ4Rdi. Courtesy @siobhanheanue.
Gulf War, UNSCOM and Operation Habitat too. Australia has had troops in the Middle East for over 25 years, not alwa… https://t.co/1P54aJiSOH
Chem suit worn by Capt Roger Noble while attached to UNSCOM in new MEAO display @AWMemorial. Brig Noble now Dep Com… https://t.co/irVLy3EgMV
@sallyjsara's headscarf and microphone in the new Middle East display at @AWMemorial help tell the story of journal… https://t.co/ledQM8XTKb
"Follow up question or joke" @Mick_Cook @pptsapper
There's still one more quarter. Give them timr @drewfore @w_westerman
Last game of the season and I had no idea the Swans had so many supporters @w_westerman #AFLGF
Missed that bit @sommecourt. Seems pretty conclusive then.
Agreed @sommecourt. Could also be someone entirely different. Fortunate in that German photos of Grant and Carter named them in caption.
@sommecourt This photo from AWM purports to show Bright (far right) in Germany. Records show he stayed in France. C… https://t.co/mshsiTYesY
Therein lies the mystery @sommecourt. Garner was from 17Bn and would have had a different colour patch. Diamond, black over green.
@sommecourt Captured at Peronne 11/09/18 and spent the remainder of the war working behind German lines. 2/2
I have @sommecourt. If those are 4Bn colour patches, based on my list of known Indigenous AIF POW, he could be 7701 Pte Walter Bright 1/2
The experiences of two Indigenous Australian #POW who spent last year of #FWW in the "Crescent Moon" camp nr Berlin: https://t.co/K4jnqfOHxW
I think @KarlJames_1945 should have one of these in his backyard @ChrisBernath. For his son, of course...
Theres also plenty of trench remnants there too @JoJohook2003. Had the pleasure of being invited onto property to check them out.
Thats right folks, Escaping The Great Escape. https://t.co/e92JAvNYVU
Long-winded! @DeadPrussianPod @iTunes
@drewfore would approve @robtswthrayguns!
I really enjoyed your book @TonyHorwitz. So far my favourite read for 2016. https://t.co/1CaVn3KjOk
My pleasure @AirmensBar!
